We have a marketplace orders app that when customers or vendors place orders in our app, we want them to be able to message us directly, but in the context of the orders.  Think of when you are on amazon and you are looking at a prior order/deal, if you want to ask amazon 'where is this'? it is helpful to attached that message to the deal in HubSpot.  In other words we want all in-app messages that a client sends to us to be in the context of a deal when they are view that deals details.  And in HubSpot we want to associate that message to their deal, by creating the conversation and then associating it to the deal.
What sort of persona do you imagine fielding these incoming messages asking for help with orders? And where do you imagine them doing it (in HubSpot?)
One of our support reps
yes, they would response in HubSpot, but ideally we would also like to surface that conversation in our UI as well

Ok. And it makes sense that the inquiry is related to a deal. Does it make sense that support reps working out of HubSpot would want to track each of these conversations as tickets through a ticket pipeline?
Maybe, but right now they are just tracking deals through the normal deal pipeline
Is 'tickets' a more available api to process messages that are deal based?

^ that's what I've been thinking about. I'm setting aside my product manager hat and putting on my solution architect hat in an effort to encourage API adoption and customer value :slightly_smiling_face:

Generally, I think the Custom Channels API is a good fit. I'd characterize the messaging aspect of your order management platform as a 'channel' to HubSpot, and a channel that only you own, only you deal in the sending and receiving of messages across that channel.
That's what this API does - you create a channel, and then there are 2 ways that admins, having installed your app, can 'connect a channel account (their particular instance of your channel) to an Inbox or Help Desk.

Inbox is what peopel are very familiar with, it's been around a long time. But it's sort of a general workspace, not closely tied to any particular HubSpot CRM object (although in-UI manual association to contacts and deals is possible)
but the issue we think we see with channels API is that the user still has to do an oAuth sign-in flow

Do you have something in place already where they log into your user interface and configure some settings? We imagine similar here, w throw up a window to a webpage you own where admins give whatever kind of permission for messages to come from your software to HubSpot. There is an alternative, more 'direct' way to create a channel account that doesnt require that front end admin auth experience.

Anyway, the other thing I wanted to say is that HubSpot is really starting to encourage support teams to run support out of Help Desk, which looks a lot like the conversation parts of the Inbox (and in fact is the same messaging backend system) but is built around how support teams manage tickets (and thus, the ticket object).
You're not locked into developing against one or the other workspace with this API - channel accounts and inboxes are the same. Features of what each can do are what are different.
Yes, we have an existing app where users login to place and see their orders.
anytime I hear 'support' I encourage people to learn more about Help Desk, and 'develop for it', even if not exclusively

"There is an alternative, more 'direct' way to create a channel account that doesnt require that front end admin auth experience."

Can you tell me about this?

another thing I'll mention is a consious omission right now is there is no sending outgoing messages on this API from object records (like a deal object). This is us really focusing in on nailing the reactive support use case beofre broadening out to other messaging use cases.

> "There is an alternative, more 'direct' way to create a channel account that doesnt require that front end admin auth experience."
Oh it's just the first of two methods detailed here <https://developers.HubSpot.com/beta-docs/guides/api/conversations/create-custom-channels#connect-channel-accounts-to-HubSpot>
in proof of concept/hacking mode I recommend starting with that method, saves you some front end development overhead
